testimony.quarrel_subject: Refused to plough land for Claudatte
Refused to allow Claudatte's daughter to be godmother at baptism
Husband refused to do ploughing for Claudatte
testimony.threat_quote: que l'on rechercheoit les remedes bien loing, et qu'ilz estoient peult estre bien pres

testimony.quarrel_subject: Dispute about carting wood - Duval spread rumor he had not delivered
testimony.threat_quote: Said he had fine horses, but did not add 'que Dieu les veuille garder de mal' as was customary

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: some days after quarrel, 8 days illness

testimony.threat_quote: qu'il n'estoit guieres blessé de ce qu'ainsy sadite femme estoit malade, et qu'il auroit moyen de faire faire ses ouvrages sans elle
qu'elle gardoit un boucquet a son marit

testimony.quarrel_subject: Claudatte expressed hatred for Claudon l'Huillier at escraigne
testimony.threat_quote: qu'il avoit des petits diables d'enfans, de gros nez grandes bouches et qu'il cherchoit le medecin bien loing et qu'il estoit bien pres

testimony.quarrel_subject: Asked if she was drunk when he found her lying face down on path in woods
Revenge - someone said 'Le diable soit qui te ramene' when Claudatte released from prison, she might have thought it was witness

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: after more than a year illness

testimony.quarrel_subject: Claudatte wanted to cause displeasure without reason

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: recovered when Claudatte offered her bread

testimony.quarrel_subject: Refused to let her participate in escraigne because of suspicions
testimony.threat_quote: qu'on ne les y porteroit guieres (referring to his children)

testimony.quarrel_subject: Father refused to allow Claudatte in escraigne; dispute over church seating

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: after being stepped on in church

timeline.subject: Claudatte Moinel and sister Jeanotte
timeline.details: PG du bailliage des Vosges informed of strong suspicions. New charges since first detention. People very upset. Receveur at Mirecourt ordered to take information secretly.

timeline.subject: Claudatte Moinel
timeline.details: Order for arrest of Claudatte, carried out same day

timeline.subject: Claudatte Moinel
timeline.details: First interrogation. Said she was 70 years old (later changed to about 50). Denied all charges.

timeline.subject: Claudatte Moinel
timeline.details: Confrontations with witnesses. Claudatte accused all witnesses of being thieves and other crimes. Maintained innocence.

timeline.subject: Claudatte Moinel
timeline.details: PG des Vosges requests question ordinaire et extraordinaire, describing her reproaches as 'peu considerables et frivols'

timeline.subject: Claudatte Moinel
timeline.details: Changed age to about 50. Discussed prior imprisonment and accusation by Ysabel Guerin 9 years before. Denied all charges.

timeline.subject: Claudatte Moinel
timeline.details: Given thumbscrews and racked, shown the strappado, but made no admissions at all

timeline.subject: Claudatte Moinel
timeline.details: Order from prevot of Mirecourt that she be renvoyée jusqu'a rappel (released pending recall)

prior_accusations.context: Accused Claudatte and her sister 9 years before execution. When Claudatte took her hand at the stake to see if she would maintain accusation, Ysabel turned her head away and refused to reply.

notable_quotes.speaker: Anne veuve Claudon l'Huillier
notable_quotes.french: que l'on rechercheoit les remedes bien loing, et qu'ilz estoient peult estre bien pres
notable_quotes.english: that they were seeking remedies far away, when they were perhaps very near
notable_quotes.context: Claudatte's ominous statement during husband's illness suggesting she was the source

notable_quotes.speaker: Demenge Beurard
notable_quotes.french: que Dieu les veuille garder de mal
notable_quotes.english: may God keep them from harm
notable_quotes.context: Customary phrase Claudatte omitted when complimenting his horses, which then died

notable_quotes.speaker: Nicolas l'Huillier (via Claudatte)
notable_quotes.french: qu'il n'estoit guieres blessé de ce qu'ainsy sadite femme estoit malade, et qu'il auroit moyen de faire faire ses ouvrages sans elle
notable_quotes.english: that he was hardly troubled that his wife was sick, and that he would have means to have his work done without her
notable_quotes.context: Threatening statement attributed to Claudatte about sick wife

notable_quotes.speaker: Jannon femme Demenge Simon
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle gardoit un boucquet a son marit
notable_quotes.english: that she was keeping a 'gift' for her husband
notable_quotes.context: Veiled threat about illness to come

notable_quotes.speaker: Ysabel veuve Demenge Jean Trop (quoting Mengeotte)
notable_quotes.french: qu'il avoit des petits diables d'enfans, de gros nez grandes bouches et qu'il cherchoit le medecin bien loing et qu'il estoit bien pres
notable_quotes.english: that he had little devil children with big noses and big mouths, and that he sought the doctor far away when he was very near
notable_quotes.context: Claudatte's hostile imprecations against Claudon l'Huillier at escraigne

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengeotte femme Bastien de la Ruelle
notable_quotes.english: that she was truly a witch
notable_quotes.context: Public accusation. Remarkably, Claudatte did not take offense but instead cherished Mengeotte more afterwards

notable_quotes.speaker: Demenge Aulbry (quoting Claudatte)
notable_quotes.french: mais qu'on ne les y porteroit guieres
notable_quotes.english: but they would not be carried there long
notable_quotes.context: Threat about his children after he excluded her from escraigne

notable_quotes.speaker: Claudatte Moinel
notable_quotes.french: O le mechant homme, larron, et un couppeur de jambe de vache
notable_quotes.english: O the wicked man, thief, and a cow-leg cutter
notable_quotes.context: Claudatte's response about Nicolas Cuguin during interrogation

notable_quotes.speaker: Claudatte Moinel
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle radresse il fault avoir patience
notable_quotes.english: for redress one must have patience
notable_quotes.context: Explaining why she didn't take legal action when called a witch

notable_quotes.speaker: Claudatte Moinel
notable_quotes.french: que la plus grande partie luy tient mais que quelques gens de bien ne l'y tiennent pas
notable_quotes.english: that the greater part hold her for one, but some good people do not
notable_quotes.context: Admitting most people consider her a witch

notable_quotes.speaker: girl at Mirecourt
notable_quotes.french: Le diable soit qui te ramene
notable_quotes.english: May the devil take whoever brings you back
notable_quotes.context: Said when Claudatte was released from prison, possibly triggering revenge

relationships.person2: Jeanotte femme Bastien Laurent dit Balozel

relationships.evidence_text: Claudatte Moinel fille Colas Jean Moinel
asked him to allow his baby daughter to be held by her daughter Jannotte at baptism
sister of Jeannette fille Jean Febuatte

economic_context.details: Multiple disputes centered on ploughing services and labor contracts. Demenge Beurard had contracted with Nicolas du Val (Claudatte's husband) for ploughing and carting wood. Claudatte asked several people to plough for her but was refused.

harms_catalog.harm_description: Very ill, believed he was sure to die, troubled in mind and body
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Refused to plough land for Claudatte
Refused to allow Claudatte's daughter to be godmother at baptism because of her reputation

harms_catalog.harm_description: Illness lasting two years, died last dimanche gras (a year ago)
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Refused to do ploughing for Claudatte

harms_catalog.harm_description: 18 months old, 'tout sec', could not stand, born 'presque sans forme de creature'
harms_catalog.method_alleged: gave wife soups and small cakes during pregnancy

harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Dispute about carting wood - Nicolas du Val spread rumor that Beurard had not delivered
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: some days after she helped him with cart, after he had delivered 3 loads
harms_catalog.method_alleged: omitted customary blessing 'que Dieu les veuille garder de mal'

harms_catalog.harm_description: Great illness of eyes and head since jour des rois; surgeon said she was poisoned
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: None specified, but Claudatte said they suspected her without voicing it

harms_catalog.victim_name: child of Jannon femme Demenge Simon
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Claudatte said she kept a 'boucquet' for her husband

harms_catalog.victim_name: child of Idatte femme Claude Didier Aulbry
harms_catalog.harm_description: Became ill immediately and remained so for 6 months
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Revenge - someone said 'Le diable soit qui te ramene' when released from prison

harms_catalog.harm_description: Fell ill and died after more than a year; 'sec et percluée de ses membres'
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: illness began immediately after Claudatte stood on her feet in church
harms_catalog.method_alleged: stepped on her feet in church

harms_catalog.harm_description: Illness of more than a year, recovered when Claudatte gave her bread
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Claudatte wanted to cause her displeasure without reason

harms_catalog.harm_description: Aged 12 months, died hardly having been ill
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Refused her request to participate in escraigne because of suspicions
harms_catalog.method_alleged: threat - said children wouldn't be carried there long

harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Father refused to allow her in escraigne, at which she was angry

Claudatte gave small cakes to wife of Demenge Simon during pregnancy

Obtained from Claudatte's house for counter-magic ritual to heal child
Jeannatte gave pears to child which caused illness
Demenge Beurard's cart for hauling wood
Horse collar - Claudatte mentioned Beurard's horse lacked one
Multiple references to horses dying or being complimented
Carting wood as part of labor contract
Claudatte accused Jean Robert of stealing these
Claudatte accused Alix of stealing garderobe from Nicolas Belot's wife
Claudatte accused Alix of stealing this from Claude Amatte's house
Belt - Claudatte accused Jean Trop of stealing curé's belt
Claudatte accused Nicolas Cugnin of stealing a scarf
Claudatte sold butter at Mirecourt that proved to contain more 'ordure' than butter
Claudatte accused Demenge Simon of stealing these grains
Claudatte accused Nicolas Cugnin of stealing stakes

spatial_references.context: Residence of Claudatte and many witnesses
Nearby village where many witnesses lived
Near Gircourt, where Claudatte's sister Jeanotte lived with Bastien Laurent dit Balozel
Claudatte's place of origin, where her father Colas Jean Moinel was from
Location of court/prison; where Claudatte had been imprisoned before; where she sold butter
Where Jean Potier was returning from when he met Claudatte; location of mill with surgeon; where tithe sheaves were allegedly stolen
Where Ysabel Guerin was executed 10 years earlier, having accused Claudatte
Fair location; Jean Trop returning from fair when he saw Claudatte lying in woods
Pilgrimage destination for healing sick child
Where Bouzeval was buried in consecrated ground
Location of seating dispute that allegedly led to illness and death of Jean Febuatte's wife
Where Jean Trop found Claudatte lying face down
Where surgeon was consulted about wife's illness
Where Claudatte was seen in strange position believed to be sabbat behavior
Where escraigne was held; manure pile

economic_hardship_indicators: Disputes over ploughing services suggest labor scarcity or economic tension
Claudatte's butter adulterated with 'ordure' suggests poverty or desperation

legal_context.redress_outcome: Would have taken witnesses to court for calling her witch, but said she had no witnesses. Also said 'qu'elle radresse il fault avoir patience' (for redress one must have patience)
legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: Previously imprisoned at Mirecourt about 9 years earlier; subjected to question (torture) at that time

hearsay_chains.content: Jean told him about meeting Claudatte and refusing to plough, believed she gave him illness

hearsay_chains.source: Mengeotte femme Bastien de la Ruelle
hearsay_chains.content: Heard Mengeotte tell Claudatte she was a witch and had killed le Gros Claudon and Jean Potier

hearsay_chains.reporter: Jeannette and Alix filles Jean Febuatte
hearsay_chains.content: Neighbors attributed death of horse to Claudatte's hatred

emotional_state_notes: Defiant - accused all witnesses of being thieves
Changed her stated age from 70 to about 50
Philosophical about being called witch - 'for redress one must have patience'
Remarkably resilient under torture - made no admissions

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: Called Claude Jean Potier a thief and 'de race de sorcier', said his mother's uncle Bouzeval had been burned (denied by witness)
Called Nicolas Cuguin 'O le mechant homme, larron, et un couppeur de jambe de vache'; said he and wife stole scarf and stakes; 'de race de sorcier'
Said Anne veuve Claudon l'Huillier had stolen wood with her husband; was present at Mirecourt when pot of butter she sold was broken and proved to contain more 'ordure' than butter
Called Demenge Beurard 'un larron, un faulx dismeur et un arracheur de bornes' (thief, false tither, boundary marker puller)
Said Demenge Simon had stolen wheat, oats and barley
Said Nicolas l'Huillier helped break door of Jean de Rapey's wife's house, had stolen wood, was 'de race de sorcier'
Called Jannon femme Demenge Simon 'une sorciere et une putain'
Called Jean Trop a thief who had stolen 'ceincture' of the curé of Girecourt
Called Jean Febuotte a 'faulx dismeur' (false tither)
Accused Jean Robert of having stolen sheaves for tithe at Avillers
Said Alix fille Jean Febuotte had stolen garderobe of Nicolas Belot's wife and a couvrechef from Claude Amatte's house; called her thief
Called Jannotte fille Jean Febuotte a thief

third_parties.name: Jeanotte femme Bastien Laurent dit Balozel
third_parties.context: Also accused of witchcraft, subject of same investigation. General reputation as witch.

third_parties.name: Jean Potier
third_parties.context: Died believing Claudatte bewitched him after he refused to plough for her. Troubled in mind and body.

third_parties.name: Claudon l'Huillier
third_parties.context: Died after 2-year illness, believed caused by Claudatte. Claudatte expressed hatred for him at escraigne.

third_parties.name: Jannotte (daughter of Claudatte)
third_parties.context: Was to be godmother to Nicolas Cuguin's child but was refused because of reputation

third_parties.name: la Bourguignotte
third_parties.context: Called Claudatte a witch, cried out 'Va te faire donner la question' after quarrel

third_parties.name: Mengeotte la Ruelle (femme Bastien de la Ruelle)
third_parties.context: Called Claudatte witch, said she had killed le Gros Claudon and Jean Potier. Remarkably, Claudatte did not take offense and cherished her more afterwards.

third_parties.name: Ysabel Guerin
third_parties.context: Burned at Savigny 9 or 10 years earlier. Had accused Claudatte and her sister. When going to stake, Claudatte took her hand to see if she would maintain accusation, but Ysabel turned her head away and refused to reply.

third_parties.name: le Gros Claudon
third_parties.context: Mengeotte accused Claudatte of killing him

third_parties.name: la Chevriere
third_parties.context: At escraigne, told Claudatte that Claudon l'Huillier said he was ill from strain or lifting too much

third_parties.name: Nicolas du Val
third_parties.context: Husband of Claudatte. Had contract with Demenge Beurard for ploughing and carting wood. Spread rumor about Beurard.

third_parties.name: Bouzeval
third_parties.context: Claudatte claimed he was burned as witch and was uncle of witness's mother. Witness denied this, said he died 'homme de bien' and was buried in consecrated ground at Charmes.

third_parties.name: Nicolas Belot's wife
third_parties.context: Claudatte accused Alix of stealing her garderobe

third_parties.name: Claude Amatte
third_parties.context: Claudatte accused Alix of stealing couvrechef from her house

third_parties.name: curé of Girecourt
third_parties.context: Claudatte accused Jean Trop of stealing his belt (ceincture)

third_parties.name: Jean de Rapey's wife
third_parties.context: Claudatte accused Nicolas l'Huillier of helping to break her door

third_parties.name: surgeon at mill of Avillers
third_parties.context: Consulted by Nicolas l'Huillier about his wife's illness; said she was poisoned and he could not cure her

third_parties.name: girl at Mirecourt (godmother of Idatte's child)
third_parties.context: Said 'Le diable soit qui te ramene' when Claudatte was released from prison, possibly triggering revenge

extraction_metadata.notes: Extremely well-documented trial with 19 detailed witness depositions. Remarkable outcome: Claudatte was released (renvoyée jusqu'a rappel) after enduring torture without confessing. Her defense strategy was unusual and aggressive - she accused all witnesses of being thieves and criminals. The trial reveals extensive social tensions around labor obligations (ploughing), baptismal godparentage, and church seating. Previous imprisonment 9 years earlier when accused by executed witch Ysabel Guerin. Sister Jeanotte also under investigation. Trial costs: just under 30 francs. Claudatte's age changed from 70 to about 50 between interrogations. Notable pattern: many harms followed refusals of labor or social obligations.
